author: Ashitha Nagesh For Metro.Co.Uk
title: Backlash after Sadiq Khan says Scottish nationalism is same as racism | Metro News
text:
Ashitha Nagesh for Metro.co.uk Saturday 25 Feb 2017 2:32 pm Sadiq made the comments in a speech published in the Daily Record (Picture: Reuters) 
Sadiq Khan was accused of comparing Scottish nationalism to racism. 
Ahead of a speech being delivered to the Scottish Labour conference in Perth, Khan said there was ‘no difference’ between nationalists and those who try to ‘divide us on the basis of our background, race or religion’. 
He also tweeted out the original copy of his speech. 
Writing in the Daily Record , he said: ‘The last thing we need now is to pit different parts of our country or sections of our society against each other – or to further fuel division or seek separation.’ 
— Sadiq Khan (@SadiqKhan) February 25, 2017 
However, after the comments sparked a storm of criticism – including from First Minister Nicola Sturgeon – his pre-briefed speech was edited to clarify that he doesn’t think Scottish nationalists are racists. 
In added text beneath his comparison, the Mayor of London now says: ‘Now of course I’m not saying that nationalists are somehow racist or bigoted – but now, more than ever, what we don’t need is more division and separation.’ Sadiq Khan has changed his pre-briefed speech text to make clear he does not think nationalists are racists. pic.twitter.com/2vim6zZsmq 
— Jamie Ross (@JamieRoss7) February 25, 2017 
He also says that London and Scotland – which both voted overwhelmingly to Remain in last year’s EU referendum – are ‘twin beacons of progressive values and hope within the United Kingdom’. 
‘Despite our shared values, there are some in Scotland who are determined to define London as Scotland’s enemy – to turn us against each other. 
‘They try to paint my city as the home of “the elite”– as a hotbed of conservatism. 
‘Well I’m in Perth today to send a clear message to all Scots that nothing could be further from the truth. 
‘Because that is not my London and that is not Labour’s London – the London that I know and love.’ Nicola Sturgeon called the comments ‘spectacularly ill-judged’ (Picture: PA) 
In response, Nicola Sturgeon tweeted that Khan’s intervention was ‘spectacularly ill-judged’. 
‘It is an insult to all those Scots who support independence for reasons of inclusion and social justice – the antithesis of what he says,’ she continued. 
‘It is a sign of the sheer desperation and moral bankruptcy that has driven so many from Scottish Labour’s ranks. Very disappointing.’ Judge praises sex offender's family for sticking by him after child porn conviction 
A spokesperson for Khan told Metro.co.uk: ‘The Mayor has been clear that now’s not the time to play on people’s fears or to pit one part of our country – or one section of our society – against each other. 
‘As he said today, there’s no difference between those who try to divide us on the basis of whether we’re English or Scottish, and those who try to divide us on the basis of our background, race or religion. 
‘Of course the Mayor is not saying that nationalists are somehow racist or bigoted, but now, more than ever- what we don’t need is more division and separation. 
‘The key point he made to conference today was that now is the time to build unity.’ More
